content: The Act is titled the "Regional Innovation and Entrepreneurship Enhancement Act of 2014." It amends Section 25 of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 to establish the Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship. The Regional Innovation and Entrepreneurship Enhancement Act of 2014 establishes the Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship to foster innovation, commercialization of new technologies, and economic growth in the United States. The office is responsible for developing policies to accelerate innovation, identifying barriers to innovation, and providing access to relevant data and research. The Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship is tasked with providing access to data, research, and technical assistance on innovation and commercialization, overseeing loan guarantee programs, and developing a strategic plan to guide its activities. The Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship focuses on advancing commercialization of research and development, setting objectives and metrics for progress. It also collaborates with other federal agencies to foster innovation nationwide and evaluates regional innovation strategies through the Regional Innovation Research and Information Program. The Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship collaborates on policies for innovation and commercialization, including small businesses and rural communities. An advisory committee provides advice to the Secretary on carrying out duties. The advisory committee prepares a report every 3 years for Congress, assessing the strategic plan and progress of the Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship, as well as its collaboration with other federal agencies. The report includes recommendations for improving the Office of Innovation and Entrepreneurship. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2018 to support these efforts. SEC. 3. REGIONAL INNOVATION PROGRAM. Amendment to Section 27 of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 to establish a Regional Innovation Program. The Secretary will establish a regional innovation program to support the development of regional innovation strategies and clusters. Grants may be awarded for activities related to forming and developing these clusters, including feasibility studies, planning, technical assistance, and enhancing communication and collaboration among participants. The regional innovation program supports collaboration among participants in a cluster, attracting new members, facilitating market development, building relationships with other clusters, and engaging with the public and government entities. Eligible recipients include states and Indian tribes. Eligible recipients include states, Indian tribes, cities, nonprofit organizations, institutions of higher education, public-private partnerships, science or research parks, Federal laboratories, economic development organizations, and consortiums supported by states or political subdivisions. The application for the regional innovation program must be submitted to the Secretary with necessary information and assurances. It should describe the cluster, its support sources, and how participation from various entities will be encouraged. Entities that might benefit from participation, including newly formed and existing participants, will be evaluated based on their potential to stimulate innovation, impact regional economic growth, access to a well-trained workforce, ability to attract funds from non-Federal sources. The Secretary will give special consideration to applications from regions negatively impacted by trade and to eligible recipients collaborating with local workforce boards. The Secretary may fund up to 50% of total activity costs and must outreach to rural communities. The Secretary will conduct outreach to rural communities and may accept funds from other Federal agencies to support grants and activities for regional innovation clusters. Additionally, a regional innovation research and information program will be established to gather, analyze, and disseminate information on best practices for regional innovation strategies. The Secretary will coordinate activities under this section with other programs at the Department of Commerce and Federal agencies to avoid duplication. Collaboration with other agencies, especially for regional innovation strategies, will be pursued. Evaluation will be conducted within 3 years of the America COMPETES Reauthorization Act of 2010.
